required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Detection of Lymphnodes Using ICG During RARP
clinical_study.official_title: Detection of Lymph Nodes by Means of Intraoperative Fluorescence Lymphography Using Indocyanine Green (ICG) During the Radical Robot-assisted Prostatectomy

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate, whether the detection of lymph nodes by means of intraoperative fluorescence lymphography as part of lymphadenectomy in robot-assisted radical prostatectomy is higher than without the use of indocyanine green (ICG).

detailed_description.textblock: ICG is a fluorescent dye that fluoresces green bound to proteins under illumination in the near-infrared range. Using this dye allows to visualize lymphatic nodes, by being injected into the tumor or directly surrounding tissue.

primary_outcome.measure: The total number of detection rate of (positive) lymph nodes using ICG

secondary_outcome.measure: Measurements of the time, that takes to remove the lymph nodes

other_outcome.measure: Determine the anatomical location of the ICG-positive lymph node

arm_group.description: Lymphadenectomy will be performed as a standard procedure

A fluorescent dye (indocyanine green) will be ultrasound-controlled preoperatively injected in the prostate. During robot-assisted radical intervention by DaVinci ® robot the lymphadenectomy is performed using the fluorescence lymphography.

intervention.description: Improvement of detection of positive lymphnodes

facility.name: St. Antonius Hospital Gronau, Department for Urology, Pediatric Urology and Urologic Oncology
